Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
XIX. THE GYRDILLERS AND NAYLERS. The Massacre of the Innocents. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
[PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Herodes. Primus et secundus Consules. Primus et secundus Milites. Prima et secunda Mulieres.]

[Scene I] Herod's court. 1. Her. Powre bewsheris aboute, Peyne of lyme and lande, Stente of youre steuenes stoute, And stille as stone ?e stande, And my carping recorde; ?e aught to dare and doute, And lere you lowe to lowte To me youre louely lorde. 2. ?e awe in felde and towne To bowe at my bidding, With reuerence and renoune, As fallis for swilk a kyng Ãe lordlyest on-lyue Who her-to is noght bowne, Be all-myghty mahounde To dede I schall hym dryue! 3. So bolde loke no man be, For to aske help ne helde But of mahounde and me, Ãat hase Ã¾is worlde in welde, To mayntayne vs emelle, For welle of welthe are we, And my cheffe helpe is he; Her-to what can ?e tell. 4. i Cons. Lord, what you likis to do All folke will be full fayne, To take entente Ã¾er-to, And none grucche Ã¾er-agayne. Ãat full wele witte shall ?e, And yf Ã¾ai wolde no?t soo, We shulde sone worke Ã¾am woo. Her. ?a! faire sirs, so shulde it bee. 5. ii Cons. Lorde, Ã¾e soth to saie, Fulle wele we undirstande, Mahounde is god werraye, And ?e ar lorde of ilke a lande. Ther-fore, so haue I seell, I rede we wayte all-way, What myrthe most mend ?ou may. Her. Certis ?e saie ryght well. 6. But I am noyed of newe, Ãat blithe may I no?t be, For thre kyngis as ?e knowe That come thurgh Ã¾is contree, And saide Ã¾ei sought a swayne. i Cons. Ãat rewlle I hope Ã¾am rewe, For hadde Ã¾er tales ben trewe, They hadde comen Ã¾is waye agayne. 7. ii Cons. We harde how Ã¾ei ?ou hight, Yf they myght fynde Ã¾at childe, For to haue tolde ?ou right, But certis Ã¾ei are begilyd. Swilke tales ar noght to trowe, Full wele wotte ilke a wight, Ãer schalle neuere man haue myght Ne maystrie unto ?ou. 8. i Cons. Ãam schamys so, for certayne, That they dar mete ?ou no more. Her. Wherfore shulde Ã¾ei be fayne To make swilke fare before; To saie a boy was borne That schulde be moste of mayne? This gadlyng schall agayne Yf Ã¾at Ã¾e deuyll had sworne; 9. For be well neuer Ã¾ei wotte, Whedir Ã¾ei wirke wele or wrang To frayne garte Ã¾am Ã¾us-gate, To seke that gedlyng gane, And swilke carping to kith. ii Cons. Nay lorde, they lered ouere latte, Youre blisse schall neuere abatte, And therfore, lorde, be blithe. [Enter Messenger.] 10. Nunc. Mahounde with-outen pere My lorde! ?ou saue! and see. Her. Messenger, come nere, And, bewcher! wele ye be. What tydyngis telles Ã¾ou, any? Nun. ?a! lorde, sen I was here, I haue sought sidis seere, And sene merueyllis full many. 11. Her. And of meruayles to move, That were most myrthe to me. Nunc. Lorde, euen as I haue seene, The soth sone schall ?e see, Yf ?e wille, here in hye. I mette tow townes betwene Thre kyngis with crounes clene, Rydand full ryally. Her. A! my blys! boy, Ã¾ou burdis to brode! [Nunc.] Sir, Ã¾er may no botment be. 12. [Her.] O we! by sonne and mone, Ãan tydis vs talis to nyght. Hopes Ã¾ou Ã¾ei will come sone Hedir, as Ã¾ei haue hight, For to telle me tythande? Nunc. Nay, lorde, Ã¾at daunce is done. Her. Why, whedir are Ã¾ei gone? Nunc. Ilkone in-to ther owne lande. 13. Her. How sais Ã¾ou, ladde? late be. Nunc. I saie for they are past. Her. What, forthe away fro me? Nunc. ?a, lord, in faitht ful faste. For I herde and toke hede How Ã¾at Ã¾ei wente, all thre, In to ther awne contre. Her. A! dogges, Ã¾e deuell ?ou spede. 14. Nunc. Sir, more of Ã¾er menyng ?itt well I undirstode How Ã¾ei hadde made offering Unto Ã¾at frely foode Ãat now of newe is borne. Ãai saie he schulde be kyng, And welde all erthely thyng. Her. Allas! Ã¾an am I lorne. 15. Fy on thaym! faytours, fy! Wille Ã¾ei be-gylle me Ã¾us. Nunc. Lorde, by ther prophicy, Ãei named his name Jesus. Her. Fy! on Ã¾e, ladde, Ã¾ou lyes! ii Cons. Hense! tyte, but Ã¾ou Ã¾e hye, With doulle her schall Ã¾ou dye, That wreyes hym on this wise. 16. Nunc. ?e wyte me all with wrang, Itt is Ã¾us and wele warre. Her. Thou lyes! false traytoure strange, Loke neuere Ã¾ou negh me nere. Vppon liffe and lyme May I Ã¾at faitour fange, Full high I schall gar hym hange, Both Ã¾e harlott and hym. 17. Nunc. I am nott worthy to wyte, Bot fares-wele, all Ã¾e heppe! i Consul. Go, in Ã¾e deueles dispite, Or I schall gar the leppe, And dere aby this bro. [Exit Messenger. Herodus. Alas! for sorowe and sighte, My woo no wighte may wryte, What deuell is best to do. 18. ii Cons. Lorde, amende youre chere, And takis no nedles noy, We schall ?ou lely lere, Ãat ladde for to distroye, Be counsaille if we cane. Her. Ãat may ?e noght come nere, For it is past two ?ere Sen Ã¾at Ã¾is bale be-gane. 19. i Cons. Lorde, Ã¾erfore haue no doute If it were foure or fyve, Gars gadir in grete rowte Youre knyghtis kene be-lyue. And biddis Ã¾am dynge to dede Alle knave childir kepte in dowte, In Bedlem and all aboute, To layte in ilke a stede. 20. ii Cons. Lorde, saue none, for youre seell, Ãat are of ii ?ere age with-inne, Ãan schall Ã¾at fandelyng felle Be-lyue his bliss schall blynne, With bale when he shall blede. Her. Sertis, ?e saie right wele, And as ?e deme ilke dele, Shall I garre do in-dede. 21. Sir knyghtis, curtayse and hende, Ãow ne nott bees nowe all newe, ?e schall fynde me youre frende, And ?e Ã¾is tyme be trewe. i Cons. What saie ?e, lorde, lette see. Her. To Bedlehem bus ?e wende, That schrewe with schame to schende Ãat menes to maistir me. 22. And a-bowte Bedlehem boght he, Bus yowe wele spere and spye, For ellis it will be waghe Ãat he losis Ã¾is Jury. And certis Ã¾at were grete schame. ii Cons. My lorde, Ã¾at wer vs lathe, And he escapid it wer skathe, And we welle worthy blame. 23. i Miles. Full sone he schall be soughte, That make I myne a-vowe. i Cons. I bide for him ?ow loghte, And latte me telle yowe howe. Go werke when ?e come there, By-cause ?e kenne hym noght, To dede they muste be brought, Knave childre, lesse and more. 24. Her. ?aa, all with-inne two ?ere, That none for speche be spared. ii Miles. Lord, howe ?e vs lere Full wele we take rewarde, And certis we schall not rest. [Exeunt.

[Scene II] Round about Bethlehem. i Miles. Comes furth, felowes, in feere; Loo! fondelyngis fynde we here. 25. i Mul. Owte on ?ou! theves, I crye! ?e slee my semely sone. ii Miles. Ther browls schall dere abye This bale Ã¾at is be-gonne, Ãer-fore lay fro Ã¾e faste. ii Mul. Allas! for doule I dye, To saue my son schall I, Aye whils my liff may last. 26. i Miles. A! dame, Ã¾e deuyll Ã¾e spede. And me, but itt be quytte. i Mul. To dye I haue no drede, I do Ã¾e wele to witte, To saue my sone so dere. i Miles. As armes! for nowe is nede, But yf we do yone dede, Ther quenys will quelle us here. 27. ii Mul. Allas! Ã¾is lothly striffe! No blisse may be my bette, Ã¾e knyght vppon his knyffe Hath slayne my sone so swette; And I hadde but hym allone. i Mul. Allas! I lose my liffe, Was neuere so wofull a wyffe, Ne halffe so wille of wone! 28. And certis, me were full lotht Ãat Ã¾ei Ã¾us harmeles ?ede. i Miles. Ãe deuell myght spede you bothe, False wicchis, are ye woode? ii Mul. Nay false lurdayns, ye lye. [i Miles.] Yf ?e be woode or wrothe, Ye schall no?t skape fro skathe, Wende we vs hense in hye. 29. i Mul. Allas! Ã¾at we wer wroughte, In worlde women to be, Ãe barne Ã¾at wee dere bought, Ãus in oure sighte to see Disputuously spill. ii Mul. And certis, Ã¾er nott is noght, The same Ã¾at Ã¾ei haue soughte, Schall Ã¾ei neuere come till. 30. i Miles. Go we to Ã¾e kyng, Of all Ã¾is contek kene I schall nott lette for no-thyng To saie as we haue sene. ii Miles. And certis, no more shall I. We haue done his bidding, We schall saie sothfastly, How so they wraste or wryng.

[Scene III] Herod's court. 31. i Miles. Mahounde, oure god of myght, Saue Ã¾e! sir herowde Ã¾e kyng! i Cons. Lorde, take kepe to youre knyght, He wille telle ?ou nowe thydingis Of bordis wher they haue bene. Her. ?aa, and Ã¾ei haue gone right, And holde Ã¾at Ã¾ei vs hight, Ãan shall solace be sene. 32. ii Miles. Lorde, as ?e demed vs to done, In contrees wher we comeâ Her. Sir, by sonne and mone, ?e are welcome home, And worthy to haue rewarde. Haue ?e geten vs Ã¾is gome? i Miles. Wher we fande felle or fone, Wittenesse we will Ã¾at Ã¾er was none. 33. ii Miles. Lord, they are dede ilkone, What wolde ?e we ded more? Her. I aske but aftir oone, Ãe kyngis tolde of before, Ãat schulde make grete maistrie; Telle vs if he be tane. i Miles. Lorde, tokenyng hadde we none To knawe Ã¾at brothell by. 34. ii Miles. In bale we haue Ã¾am brought A-boute all Bedleham towne. Her. Ye lye, ?oure note is nought! Ãe deueles of helle ?ou droune! So may Ã¾at boy be fledde, For in waste haue ?e wroght Or that same ladde be sought, Schalle I neure byde in bedde. 35. [? i Cons.] We will wende with you Ã¾an To dynge Ã¾at dastard doune. [? ii Cons.] Asarme! euere ilke man, That holdis of mahounde. Wer they a thousand skore, This bargayne schall Ã¾ai banne Comes aftir as yhe canne, For we will wende be-fore. [Exeunt.
